source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: Fatigue testing was performed on unirradiated and irradiated materials. Fully reversed uniaxial fatigue tests were conducted at constant total strain amplitudes between 0.3 and 1.4% at 316 in air.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: Fatigue crack growth testing was conducted on conventional compact tension (CT) specimens at 293 and 561 K. Unirradiated material was tested in air and water, and irradiated material was tested in air.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: Fatigue crack growth testing was conducted on conventional compact tension (CT) specimens at 293 and 561 K. Unirradiated material was tested in air and water, and irradiated material was tested in air.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: Crack growth rates, expressed as a function of ΔK (applied stress intensity range), were determined to be insensitive to neutron irradiation, but were increased by a factor of 2 to 4 in water, depending on oxygen content of the water.

evidence_span: In general, the softer zirconiums have longer fatigue lives than Zircaloy.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_030_chunk6
evidence_span: Normalized crack growth thresholds determined at a cyclic load frequency of ${ \mathfrak { s o } } \mathbf { H z }$ are given in Table 7. These correspond to threshold $\Delta K$ values ranging from approximately 1.2 to $2 . 2 \ \mathrm { M P a } \sqrt { \mathbf { m } }$ , depending on temperature and load ratio.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_030_chunk6
evidence_span: Crack growth rates in air at $\Im 6 1 \mathrm { ~ \bf ~ K ~ }$ for the unirradiated material are given in Fig. 11. For a load ratio, $R = 0 . 8$ , the crack growth rate in air at 561 K is given to a good approximation by the relationship $d a / d N = ( 5 . 4 7 \times 1 0 ^ { - 1 1 } ) \Delta K ^ { 3 . 1 3 }$ where da/dN is in metres per cycle and $\Delta K$ is given in $\mathbf { M P a } \sqrt { \mathbf { m } }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_030_chunk6
evidence_span: Crack growth rates measured in elevated temperature pressurized water are plotted, as a function of $\Delta K ,$ in Fig. 1. It can be seen that water at $6 . 8 9 \mathrm { M P a }$ and 561 K and containing 0.1 to $0 . 2 \ \mathsf { p p m }$ of dissolved oxygen approximately doubles the crack growth rate at $3 \ \mathbf { H z }$ in comparison to the rate in air at the same temperature and frequency.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_030_chunk6
evidence_span: Increasing the oxygen content to 6 to $8 \ \mathsf { p p m }$ further increases the growth rate three to four times the corresponding rate in air.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_030_chunk6
evidence_span: Crack growth rates measured in the irradiated specimens at 561 K are shown in Fig. 13. For neither the higher nor the lower fast neutron fluences do the measured crack growth rates in the irradiated material differ significantly from those measured in the unirradiated reference Zircaloy-4 at the same frequency and load ratio.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_030_chunk6
evidence_span: Tests were conducted primarily in the temperature range of BWR interest, 561 to 616 K. Materials were irradiated to fluences between 1 to $1 5 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \ \mathrm { n / m ^ { 2 } }$ $( E > 1 \ \mathbf { M e V } )$
